titlStmt.titl: Assessment of Discharge Process from the Pediatric Cardiology Unit

citation.biblCit: Mackie, Andrew; Klassen, Keltie; Schuh, Michelle; Schendel, Sheena; Morrison, Lisa; Rankin, Kathryn; Robert, Cheri; Islam, Sunjidatul, 2016, "Assessment of Discharge Process from the Pediatric Cardiology Unit", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10905, UAL Dataverse, V2

titlStmt.titl: Assessment of Discharge Process from the Pediatric Cardiology Unit
titlStmt.altTitl: Assessment of Pediatric Cardiology Discharge Teaching

stdyInfo.abstract: Using a survey research design with a convenience sample, the investigators will evaluate discharge teaching in the Pediatric Cardiology Unit at the Stollery Children's Hospital. The survey tool will provide anonymous data from parents related to their children's hospitalization and discharge from hospital.

sumDscr.universe: Parents, guardians and caregivers of pediatric patients who are discharged from the Pediatric Cardiology Unit at the Stollery Children's Hospital.

dataColl.frequenc: Data was collected at time of discharge and two weeks after discharge.
dataColl.sampProc: The target sample was 200 study participants; the actual sample was 181 study participants, chosen through a convenience sample.

sources.dataSrc: Readiness for Hospital Discharge Scale (RDHS); Care Transitions Measure (CTM-3); Quality of Discharge Teaching Scale (QDTS)

dataColl.collMode: Self-administered questionnaire: Paper; Self-administered questionnaire: Web-based
dataColl.collSitu: Two sets of questionnaires were administered two weeks apart to assess the quality of discharge teaching from the inpatient unit. The questionnaires included questions about the child's hospital stay and validated tools that measure the quality of discharge teaching. The first questionnaire was completed on the date of discharge and the second questionnaire set was completed two weeks after discharge; the second set of questionnaires was sent out either by e-mail (through EPro, Women and Children's Health Research Institute) or by regular mail (with a self-addressed, stamped envelope for return) as preferred by the participant.

useStmt.conditions: Access to deidentified data may be permitted for external researchers, with limitations. The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access.

citation.biblCit: Schuh, M., Schendel, S., Klassen, K., Morrison, L., Rankin, K. N., Robert, C., & Mackie, A. S. (2014). Assessment of the discharge process in a tertiary-care pediatric cardiology unit. Canadian Journal of Cardiology, 30(10, Supplement), S187-S188.

Schuh, M., Schendel, S., Klassen, K., Morrison, L., Rankin, K. N., Robert, C., & Mackie, A. S. (2014). Assessment of the discharge process in a tertiary-care pediatric cardiology unit. Canadian Journal of Cardiology, 30(10, Supplement), S187-S188.

Schuh, M., Schendel, S., Islam, S., Klassen, K., Morrison, L., Rankin, K. N., Robert, C. and Mackie, A. S. (2016), Parent readiness for discharge from a tertiary care pediatric cardiology unit. J Spec Pediatr Nurs, 21: 139–146.
